pr_title: JLBP 21: Upload artifacts to Maven Central

timeline.bodyText: I didn't find this sentence useful. Should this paragraph guide readers to take some action upon firewall problem?
timeline.author: suztomo
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,28 @@
+---
+jlbp:
+  id: JLBP-21
+permalink: /JLBP-21
+---
+# Upload artifacts to Maven Central
+
+Developers expect to find artifacts in [Maven Central](https://repo1.maven.org/maven2/). All artifacts
+intended for public consumption
+should be published in the [Maven Central repository maintained by Sonatype](https://search.maven.org). Even if a project is not built with Maven,
+its artifacts can and should be published to Maven Central.
+
+From here the artifacts are mirrored to many different local and public repositories. 
+
+While Maven supports additional remote repositories,
+this requires special configuration
+in the pom.xml file. Tools other than Maven itself that 
+use the repository system do not always read this information from the 
+pom.xml files and often cannot load artifacts that are not available in Maven Central.
+
+Developers who manually search for particular artifacts usually start at
+Maven Central and sometimes don't look elsewhere.
+
+Firewalls sometimes block access to third party repositories.

replies.bodyText: The action to take is to publish artifacts in Maven Central, not in the repositories the firewall blocks.
replies.author: elharo

replies.bodyText:
I misread this. Now I know this sentence is here to support "Upload artifacts to Maven Central".
My confusion came from the fact that my previous workplace blocked Maven Central and copied only approved artifacts. So Maven Central is not immune to firewalls.
replies.author: suztomo

replies.bodyText: For companies that maintains their own repositories inside their network, Maven Central is a third party repository. They sometimes block Maven Central by firewalls or HTTP proxy.
replies.author: suztomo

replies.bodyText: Do you still need this line of Maven Central's immunity against firewalls? Companies may block Maven Central by firewalls or HTTP proxy. Having said that, it's easier for them to host a repository mirror inside their network when every library is hosted in Maven Central.
replies.author: suztomo

replies.bodyText:
Firewalls sometimes block access to third party repositories.

I still think this paragraph is unnecessary, because sometimes firewalls block access to Maven Central.
replies.author: suztomo

replies.bodyText: I suspect it happens, but rarely. When it does, there's nothing a library developer can do about it. If the end user developer's firewall is blocking maven central, they have to fix that before they can build anything.
replies.author: elharo

replies.bodyText:
Right. The existence of the restricted networks also supports having everything in Maven Central. 2 items I don't think this paragraph is right:

Maven Central itself is a third party repository.
This paragraph says firewalls do not block Maven Central.

How about saying this?
"If a library is hosted in certain repositories other than Maven Central, then it would a chore for network administrators maintaining a restricted network to setup additional mirrors or firewall rules of the repositories"
replies.author: suztomo

replies.bodyText: done
replies.author: elharo

timeline.bodyText: Did you have specific problems in your mind when you wrote this? I want to see it in this document.
timeline.author: suztomo
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,28 @@
+---
+jlbp:
+  id: JLBP-21
+permalink: /JLBP-21
+---
+# Upload artifacts to Maven Central

replies.bodyText: Typically it's happened with things like Gradle and SBT. I'd have to spend some time digging up specific cases.
replies.author: elharo

replies.bodyText: Looking forward.
replies.author: suztomo

replies.bodyText: one example: grpc/grpc-java#7276
replies.author: elharo

replies.bodyText: Thanks. If I read that correctly, grpc-java has always published the library to Maven Central, but not always with JCenter. So this problem cannot be fixed by uploading some artifacts to Maven Central.
replies.author: suztomo

replies.bodyText: I don't think that's true. Regardless, we've hit this repeatedly, every few months, in one context or another. I don't think we should list every example here, which might be resolved in the future.
replies.author: elharo

replies.bodyText: another example from a quick google search: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/58239027/how-to-force-maven-to-use-jcenter-repoistory
replies.author: elharo

replies.bodyText: (You definitely have troubleshooted more cases than I have.) No need to list every occurrence. I want to learn just one case where this JLBP "Upload artifacts to Maven Central" would have prevented it.
replies.author: suztomo

replies.bodyText: Ktor is a Kotlin library. https://ktor.io/docs/quickstart-index.html#set-up-a-ktor-project I guess jcenter is Kotlin's standard.
replies.author: suztomo

replies.bodyText: That Ktor involves Kotlin is not relevant. Someone tried to use this library from Maven and it failed because it wasn't in Maven Central. This is a very common occurrence. I've encountered it multiple times myself. There are many different causes for it, but one solution. Deploy to Maven Central.
replies.author: elharo

replies.bodyText:
Yes, one solution is for the Kotlin library maintainers to deploy the library to Maven central. Another solution, which I believe most common, is to include repositories in pom.xml.
From Java developers' perspective, having everything in Maven Central is simpler. I just feel that it's strange to recommend Kotlin library maintainers to publish their libraries to Maven Central when their standard is to use jcenter.
replies.author: suztomo

replies.bodyText: It does not seem to be the Kotlin standard to use JCenter. Regardless, I have no compunctions about recommending they use Maven Central instead. There are many, many cases where using other repos causes needless pain for developers. None of these are unfixable, but there's no reason to make developers worry about this when there's such a simple solution. I do not want to litigate each and every instance of this problem.
replies.author: elharo

replies.bodyText: Are you aware of: https://maven.google.com/web/index.html ??
replies.author: lesv

replies.bodyText: Yes. I think we've had problems with android dependencies in the past for the reasons addressed in this JLBP. Tools start to break when they don't find artifacts in Maven Central. Yes there's usually some way to fix it, but the JLBPs don't stop at what works if you toggle the right knobs and flip the right switches. The JLBPs recommend practices that make development as easy as possible for clients. It's easier if the artifacts are in maven Central, the default where everything looks, than if they're in some other repo.
replies.author: elharo

replies.bodyText:
And still another case of this that bit me today in one of our own repos:
[ERROR] Failed to execute goal on project google-api-client-android: Could not resolve dependencies for project com.google.api-client:google-api-client-android:jar:1.31.2-SNAPSHOT: Could not find artifact com.google.android.google-play-services:google-play-services:jar:1 in central (https://repo.maven.apache.org/maven2) -> [Help 1]

I stand behind this one and I think we should publish it. Not uploading jars to Maven Central can be made to work, but that's not enough. Everyone's job is easier if libraries put their jars in Maven Central.
replies.author: elharo

replies.bodyText:
One part of Google (this PR JLBP 21) is going to say everyone should put artifacts to Maven Central. Another part of Google may continue to use https://maven.google.com/web/index.html.
Do you think it's worth getting input from Android team?
replies.author: suztomo

replies.bodyText: Feel free to ask them to comment on this PR. However in general we should not assume that just because Google does something, it is ideal. Teams often optimize for local convenience and development velocity, even when it costs external developers more time and effort. The JLBPs are about how to publish artifacts in a way that is easiest for customers to consume, even at the cost of extra effort for library developers.
replies.author: elharo

timeline.bodyText: Clarify "additional remote repositories" and "third party repositories".
timeline.author: suztomo

replies.bodyText: done
replies.author: elharo
